results.headline: Scientific Trek Turns Into a Game of Spot the Alien

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Thing

results.summary_short: “The Thing” is a prequel to the 1982 film about scientists in the Antarctic and the menacing alien guest who wasn’t invited to the party.

results.headline: Obsessed Men in Pursuit of Friends With Feathers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Big Year

results.summary_short: In the new comedy “The Big Year,” Steve Martin, Jack Black and Owen Wilson play men driven by passion and compelled to compete.

results.headline: One Man’s Crusade Is More a Portrait of a Land and Its Culture

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oka!

results.summary_short: “Oka!,” which makes a star out of the small Central African Republic town at its center, is based on an unpublished memoir by Louis Sarno.

results.headline: Forget All That Stuff About Dirty, Dancing Is Downright Dangerous

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Footloose

results.summary_short: Craig Brewer’s remake of the 1984 movie “Footloose” stars Julianne Hough, the newcomer Kenny Wormald and Dennis Quaid.

results.headline: A Hometown Visit, en Route to the Past

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fireflies in the Garden

results.summary_short: “Fireflies in the Garden” toggles between a family’s present-tense strained relationships and a writer’s memories of his unhappy childhood.

results.headline: Mopping Up His Life After Years in Prison

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Father of Invention

results.summary_short: In “Father of Invention,” Kevin Spacey plays a TV snake-oil salesman just out of prison.

results.headline: Examining Everything From the Big Bang to Twitter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Connected: A Declaration of Interdependence

results.summary_short: Tiffany Shlain’s “Connected” is a documentary essay and personal memoir that examines the social topology of the digital era and the evolutionary origins of human civilization.

results.headline: Multitasking on the Slopes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Chalet Girl

results.summary_short: In “Chalet Girl,” Felicity Jones plays a girl from the wrong side of the tracks whose charm wins over the upper-class snobs — and Ed Westwick — in the Austrian Alps.

results.headline: For Three Teenagers, Easing Life’s Struggles Through Poetry

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of To Be Heard

results.summary_short: “To Be Heard” tracks the intertwining trajectories of three underprivileged teenagers whose lives are transformed by their participation in a slam-poetry program.

results.headline: Two Early Films From John Akomfrah

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seven Songs for Malcolm X

results.summary_short: Two early films from the British-Ghanian documentarian John Akomfrah are on view at the Maysles Cinema in Harlem, one eyeing black history, the other the future.

results.headline: Harvey Weinstein Is Under the Microscope Again

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project

results.summary_short: “Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project,” from the director Barry Avrich, is a virtual tribute to the man who co-founded Miramax Films.

results.headline: Horrors of a Coming War Painted in a 1935 Meeting
results.display_title: Varian and Putzi: A 20th Century Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Varian and Putzi: A 20th Century Tale

results.summary_short: Varian Fry and Ernst Hanfstaengl’s 1935 encounter and their actions during World War II spurred Richard Kaplan to tackle their lives and histories in the film “Varian and Putzi.”

results.headline: Gore, Grime and One Creepy Guy in an Underground Garage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Human Centipede 2: Full Sequence

results.summary_short: In Tom Six’s sequel “The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence),” he trips over himself trying to outdo the first lurid wallow.

results.headline: For a Bourgeois Frenchman, Happiness Is a Garret Away
results.display_title: The Women on the Sixth Floor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Women on the Sixth Floor

results.summary_short: “The Women on the 6th Floor” involves a bourgeois Parisian businessman who discovers a happy world with a small group of Spanish maids living in his family’s building.

results.headline: A Trek From Loss and Grief to a Life Given Greater Meaning

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Way

results.summary_short: In Emilio Estevez’s film “The Way,” an ophthalmologist walks the Way of St. James.

results.headline: Mardi Gras as an Explosion of Gay Rights

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sons of Tennessee Williams

results.summary_short: “The Sons of Tennessee Williams,” a documentary by Tim Wolff, ? tracks a half-century of the gay civil-rights movement through the lens of Mardi Gras celebrations in New Orleans.

results.headline: Before the ‘I Do,’ the Self-Discovery

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The One

results.summary_short: “The One,” about a man engaged to be married who discovers that he is gay, is a coming-out film by Caytha Jentis.

results.headline: Estranged Bedfellows

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ides of March

results.summary_short: In “The Ides of March,” George Clooney, as the governor of Pennsylvania, keeps his cool while inflaming the passions of Democratic primary voters.

results.headline: Bare-Knuckle Bots, Showing Their Mettle in the Boxing Ring

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Real Steel

results.summary_short: In “Real Steel,” a robot boxing movie starring Hugh Jackman, machines replace humans as prizefighting combatants.

results.headline: Breaking the Chains of Chinese Feudalism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1911

results.summary_short: A patriotic epic about the Chinese struggle to shake off imperial rule, “1911” is also Jackie Chan’s 100th film.
